preblock.preline: Bacterial vaginosis(BV), also known asvaginal bacteriosisorGardnerella vaginitis,cite bookBorchardtKenneth A.Sexually transmitted diseases : epidemiology, pathology, diagnosis, and treatment1997CRC PressBoca Raton [u.a.]97808493947684https://books.google.ca/books?idis adiseaseof thevaginacaused by excessivebacteria.cite journalClarkNatalieTalReshefSharmaHarshaSegarsJamesMicrobiota and Pelvic Inflammatory DiseaseSeminars in Reproductive Medicine32012014http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4148456/043–0491526-800410.1055/s-0033-1361822Common symptoms include increasedvaginal dischargethat often smells like fish. The discharge is usually white or gray in color.DysuriaBurning with urinationmay occur.Itching is uncommon.Occasionally there may be no symptoms.cite webWhat are the symptoms of bacterial vaginosis?http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/bacterialvag/conditioninfo/Pages/symptoms.aspxhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/3 March 20152013-05-21Having BV increases the risk of infection by a number of othersexually transmitted infectionsincludingHIV/AIDS.cite journalKenyonCColebundersRCrucittiTThe global epidemiology of bacterial vaginosis: a systematic review.American journal of obstetrics and gynecologyDecember 20132096505–232365998910.1016/j.ajog.2013.05.006It also increases the risk ofpretermearly deliveryamong pregnant women.cite bookQueenaJohn T. .SpongCatherine YLockwoodCharles J., editorsQueenan's management of high-risk pregnancy : an evidence-based approach2622012Wiley-BlackwellChichester, West Sussex97804706557646thcite webWhat are the treatments for bacterial vaginosis (BV)?http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/bacterialvag/conditioninfo/Pages/treatments.aspxhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/4 March 20152013-07-15

BV is caused by an imbalance of the naturally occurring bacteria in the vagina.There is a change in the most common type of bacteria and a hundred to thousandfold increase in total numbers of bacteria present.Risk factors includedouching, new or multiple sex partners,antibiotics, and using anintrauterine deviceamong others.However, it is not considered a sexually transmitted infection.cite webhttp://www.cdc.gov/std/bv/stdfact-bacterial-vaginosis.htmBacterial Vaginosis – CDC Fact SheetMarch 11, 2014[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]2 Mar 2015Diagnosis is suspected based on the symptoms and may be verified by testing the vaginal discharge and finding a higher than normal vaginalpHand large numbers of bacteria.BV is often confused with avaginal yeast infectionorinfection with Trichomonas.cite journalMashburnJEtiology, diagnosis, and management of vaginitis.Journal of midwifery & women's health2006516423–301708193210.1016/j.jmwh.2006.07.005

Usually treatment is with an antibiotic, such asclindamycinormetronidazole. These medications may also be used in the second or third trimesters ofpregnancy. However, the condition often recurs following treatment.Probioticsmay help prevent re-occurrence.cite journalDondersGGZodzikaJRezebergaDTreatment of bacterial vaginosis: what we have and what we miss.Expert opinion on pharmacotherapyApril 2014155645–572457985010.1517/14656566.2014.881800It is unclear if the use of probiotics or antibiotics affects pregnancy outcomes.cite journalOthmanMNeilsonJPAlfirevicZProbiotics for preventing preterm labour.The Cochrane database of systematic reviews24 January 20071CD00594117253567

BV is the most common vaginal infection in women of reproductive age.cite webBacterial Vaginosis (BV): Condition Informationhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/bacterialvag/conditioninfo/Pages/default.aspxhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/3 March 20152013-05-21The percentage of women affected at any given time varies between 5% and 70%.BV is most common in parts of Africa and least common in Asia and Europe.In the United States about 30% of women between the ages of 14 and 49 are affected.cite webBacterial Vaginosis (BV) Statistics Prevalencehttp://www.cdc.gov/std/bv/stats.htmcdc.gov3 March 2015September 14, 2010Rates vary considerably betweenethnic groupswithin a country.While BV like symptoms have been described for much of recorded history, the first clearly documented case occurred in 1894.

article.heading: Signs and symptoms
article.paragraph: Common symptoms include increasedvaginal dischargethat usually smells like fish. The discharge is often white or gray in color. There may beDysuriaburning with urination. Occasionally there may be no symptoms.

The discharge coats the walls of the vagina, and is usually without significant irritation, pain, orerythema(redness), although mildPruritusitchingcan sometimes occur. By contrast, the normal vaginal discharge will vary in consistency and amount throughout themenstrual cycleand is at its clearest atovulationabout 2 weeks before themenstruationperiodstarts. Some practitioners claim that BV can be asymptomatic in almost half of affected women,cite journalSchwebke JRAsymptomatic bacterial vaginosis: response to therapyAm. J. Obstet. Gynecol.18361434–920001112050710.1067/mob.2000.107735though others argue that this is often a misdiagnosis.cite journalForney LJ, Foster JA, Ledger WThe vaginal flora of healthy women is not always dominated by Lactobacillus speciesJournal of Infections Diseases194101468–920061705408010.1086/508497
article.heading: Causes
article.paragraph: mainList of bacterial vaginosis microbiotaHealthy vaginal microbiota consists of species which do not cause symptoms, infections, or negatively affect pregnancy. It is dominated mainly by Lactobacillus species.cite journalPetrovaMariya I.LievensElkeMalikShwetaImholzNicoleLebeerSarahLactobacillus species as biomarkers and agents that can promote various aspects of vaginal healthFrontiers in Physiology620151664-042X10.3389/fphys.2015.00081BV is defined by the disequilibrium in theList of microbiota species of the lower reproductive tract of womenvaginal microbiotawith decline in the number oflactobacilli. While the infection involves a number of bacteria, it is believed that most infections start withGardnerella vaginaliscreating abiofilmwhich allows otheropportunistic infectionopportunistic bacteriato thrive.cite journalPattersonJ. L.Stull-LaneA.GirerdP. H.JeffersonK. K.Analysis of adherence, biofilm formation and cytotoxicity suggests a greater virulence potential of Gardnerella vaginalis relative to other bacterial-vaginosis-associated anaerobesMicrobiology12 November 20091562392–39910.1099/mic.0.034280-0

One of the main risks for developing BV isdouching, which alters the vaginal flora and predisposes women to developing BV.cite journalCottrell BHAn Updated Review of Evidence to Discourage DouchingMCN, the American Journal of Maternal/Child Nursing352102–107; quiz 107–920102021595110.1097/NMC.0b013e3181cae9daDouching is strongly discouraged by theU.S. Department of Health and Human Servicesand various medical authorities, for this and other reasons.

BV is a risk factor forpelvic inflammatory disease, HIV, sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and reproductive and obstetric disorders or negative outcomes. It is possible for sexually inactive persons to develop bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis may sometimes affect women aftermenopause. Subclinical iron deficiency may correlate with bacterial vaginosis in early pregnancy.cite journalVerstraelen H, Delanghe J, Roelens K, Blot S, Claeys G, Temmerman MSubclinical iron deficiency is a strong predictor of bacterial vaginosis in early pregnancyBMC Infect. J. Obstet. Gynecol.1942381–6February 200616458633236710410.1016/j.ajog.2005.07.047http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0002-9378(05)01131-2Exposure to the spermicidenonoxynol-9does not affect the risk of developing bacterial vaginosis.cite journalWilkinsonDRamjeeGTholandiMRutherfordGNonoxynol-9 for preventing vaginal acquisition of sexually transmitted infections by women from men.The Cochrane database of systematic reviews20024CD00393912519623

Having aWomen who have sex with womenfemale partnerincreases the risk of BV by 60%. The bacteria associated with BV have been isolated fromMale reproductive systemmale genitalia. BV microbiota have been found in thepenis,coronal sulcus, andmale urethra, in the male partners of infected females. Thoseuncircumcisedpartners may act as aNatural reservoirreservoirincreasing the likelihood of acquiring an infection after sexual intercourse. Another mode of transmission of BV associated microbiota is to a female sexual partner via the skin-to-skin transfer. BV may be transmitted via the perineal enteric bacteria from the microbiota of the female and male genitalia.
article.heading: Diagnosis
article.paragraph: File:Bacterial vaginosis workup.jpgthumbApH indicatorto detect vaginal alkalinization (here showing approximately pH 8), and amicroscope slideto microscopically detectclue cells.To make a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis, a swab from inside the vagina should be obtained. These swabs should be tested for:

list.listitem: A characteristic "fishy" odor onWet mount#Wet mount or temporary mountwet mount. This test, called thewhiff test, is performed by adding a small amount ofpotassium hydroxideto amicroscopic slidecontaining the vaginal discharge. A characteristicfishy odoris considered a positive whiff test and is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.

Loss ofacidity. To control bacterial growth, the vagina is normally slightly acidic with apHof 3.84.2. A swab of the discharge is put ontolitmus paperto check its acidity. A pH greater than 4.5 is considered alkaline and is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.

The presence ofclue cellson wet mount. Similar to the whiff test, the test for clue cells is performed by placing a drop ofsodium chloridesolution on a slide containing vaginal discharge. If present, clue cells can be visualized under a microscope. They are so-named because they give a clue to the reason behind the discharge. These areepithelialcells that are coated with bacteria.

article.paragraph: Two positive results in addition to the discharge itself are enough to diagnose BV. If there is no discharge, then all three criteria are needed.cite journalAmsel R, Totten PA, Spiegel CA, Chen KC, Eschenbach D, Holmes KKNonspecific vaginitis. Diagnostic criteria and microbial and epidemiologic associationsAm. J. Med.74114–221983660037110.1016/0002-9343(83)91112-9primary-source inlineDecember 2011Differential diagnosis for bacterial vaginosis includes the following:cite webDiseases Characterized by Vaginal Dischargehttp://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment/2010/vaginal-discharge.htmcdc.govCenters for Disease Control and Prevention

list.listitem: Trichomoniasis, an infection caused byTrichomonas vaginalis.

article.paragraph: The Center For Disease Control (CDC) defines STIs as "a variety of clinical syndromes and infections caused by pathogens that can be acquired and transmitted through sexual activity."Workowski, Kimberly A. and Bolan, Gail A. Sexually Transmitted Diseases Treatment Guidelines, 2015. MMWR Recomm Rep 2015; volume 64, issue 3:p.1.But the CDC does not specifically identify BV as sexually transmitted infection.
article.heading: Amsel criteria
article.paragraph: In clinical practice BV can be diagnosed using the Amsel criteria:

list.listitem: Release of a fishy odor on addingalkali10%potassium hydroxide(KOH) solution.

article.paragraph: At least three of the four criteria should be present for a confirmed diagnosis.cite webhttp://www.guideline.gov/summary/summary.aspx?doc_idNational guideline for the management of bacterial vaginosis (2006)Clinical Effectiveness Group, British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH)A modification of the Amsel criteria accepts the presence of two instead of three factors, and is considered equally diagnostic.
article.heading: Gram stain
article.paragraph: An alternative is to use a Gram-stained vaginal smear, with the Hay/Isoncite journalIson CA, Hay PEValidation of a simplified grading of Gram stained vaginal smears for use in genitourinary medicine clinicsSex Transm Infect786413–5200212473800175833710.1136/sti.78.6.413criteria or the Nugentcite journalNugent RP, Krohn MA, Hillier SLReliability of diagnosing bacterial vaginosis is improved by a standardized method of gram stain interpretationJ. Clin. Microbiol.292297–30119911706728269757http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?viewcriteria. The Hay/Ison criteria are defined as follows:

list.listitem: Grade 2 (Intermediate): Mixed flora with some Lactobacilli present, but Gardnerella or Mobiluncus morphotypes also present.
Grade 3 (Bacterial Vaginosis): Predominantly Gardnerella and/or Mobiluncus morphotypes. Few or absent Lactobacilli. (Hay et al., 1994)

article.paragraph: Gardnerella vaginalis is the main culprit in BV. Gardnerella vaginalis is a short rod (coccobacillus). Hence, the presence of clue cells and gram variable coccobacilli are indicative or diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis.

The standards for research are the Nugent criteria.In this scale, a score of 0-10 is generated from combining three other scores. article.paragraph: DNA hybridizationtesting with Affirm VPIII was compared to the Gram stain using the Nugent criteria.cite journalGazi H, Degerli K, Kurt O, Teker A, Uyar Y, Caglar H, Kurutepe S, Surucuoglu SUse of DNA hybridization test for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis in women with symptoms suggestive of infectionAPMIS11411784–720061707885910.1111/j.1600-0463.2006.apm_485.xSurucuogluThe Affirm VPIII test may be used for the rapid diagnosis of BV in symptomatic women but uses expensive proprietary equipment to read results, and does not detect other pathogens that cause BV, including Prevotella spp, Bacteroides spp, & Mobiluncus spp.
article.heading: Prevention
article.paragraph: Some steps suggested to lower the risk include: notdouching, avoiding sex, or limiting the number of sex partners.cite webhttp://www.cdc.gov/std/bv/stdfact-bacterial-vaginosis.htmBacterial Vaginosis – CDC Fact SheetMarch 11, 2014[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]6 May 2015

One review concluded that probiotics may help prevent re-occurrence.Another review found that while there is tentative evidence it is not strong enough to recommend their use for this purpose.cite journalMastromarinoPaolaVitaliBeatriceMoscaLucianaBacterial vaginosis: a review on clinical trials with probioticshttp://www.newmicrobiologica.org/PUB/allegati_pdf/2013/3/229.pdfNew Microbiologica201336229–23823912864

Antibiotic treatment of male partners could re-establish the normal microbiota of the male uro-genital tract. BV associated bacteria in or on the male genitals may promote relapse, reinfection of, women with BV. Treating the male partner is an effective and safe intervention and offers the advantage of preventing the recurrence of infection.cite journalAmaya-GuioJairoMartinez-VelasquezMercy YolimaViveros-CarreñoDavid AndresSierra-BarriosEloisa MercedesGrillo-ArdilaCarlos FAmaya-GuioJairoAntibiotic treatment for the sexual partners of women with bacterial vaginosis201510.1002/14651858.CD011701
article.heading: Treatment
Antibiotics
article.paragraph: Treatment is typically with theantibioticsmetronidazoleorclindamycin.They can be either given by mouth or applied inside the vagina.cite journalOduyebo OO, Anorlu RI, Ogunsola FTThe effects of antimicrobial therapy on bacterial vaginosis in non-pregnant womenCochrane Database Syst Rev3CD00605520091958837910.1002/14651858.CD006055.pub2OduyeboOyinlola OAbout 10% to 15% of people; however, do not improve with the first course of antibiotics and recurrence rates of up to 80% have been documented.cite journalSenokAbiola CVerstraelenHansTemmermanMarleenBottaGiuseppe ASenokAbiola CProbiotics for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis200910.1002/14651858.CD006289.pub219821358Recurrence rates are increased with sexual activity with the same pre-/posttreatment partner and inconsistent condom use although estrogen-containing contraceptives decrease recurrence.cite journalBradshaw CS, Vodstrcil LA, Hocking JS, Law M, Pirotta M, Garland SM, De Guingand D, Morton AN, Fairley CKRecurrence of bacterial vaginosis is significantly associated with posttreatment sexual activities and hormonal contraceptive use.Clinical infectious diseases : an official publication of the Infectious Diseases Society of America566777–86Mar 20132324317310.1093/cid/cis1030When clindamycin is given to pregnant women symptomatic with BV before 22 weeks of gestation the risk of pre-term birth before 37 weeks of gestation is lower.cite journalLamontRonald F.Nhan-ChangChia-LingSobelJack D.WorkowskiKimberlyConde-AgudeloAgustinRomeroRobertoTreatment of abnormal vaginal flora in early pregnancy with clindamycin for the prevention of spontaneous preterm birth: a systematic review and metaanalysisAmerican Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology20532011177–1900002937810.1016/j.ajog.2011.03.04722071048
Other antibiotics that may work include macrolides, lincosamides, nitroimidazoles, and penicillins.

Bacterial vaginosis is not considered asexually transmitted infection, and treatment of a male sexual partner of a woman with bacterial vaginosis is not recommended.cite journalMehta SDSystematic review of randomized trials of treatment of male sexual partners for improved bacteria vaginosis outcomes in womenSex Transm Dis3910822–30October 20122300770910.1097/OLQ.0b013e3182631d89cite journalPotter JShould sexual partners of women with bacterial vaginosis receive treatment?Br J Gen Pract49448913–8November 1999108186621313567http://openurl.ingenta.com/content/nlm?genre
article.heading: Probiotics
article.paragraph: A 2009 Cochrane review found tentative but insufficient evidence for probiotics as a treatment for BV.cite journalSenokACVerstraelenHTemmermanMBottaGAProbiotics for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis.The Cochrane database of systematic reviews7 October 20094CD00628919821358A 2014 review reached the same conclusion.cite journalHuangHSongLZhaoWEffects of probiotics for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis in adult women: a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.Archives of gynecology and obstetricsJune 201428961225–3424318276A 2013 review found some evidence supporting the use of probiotics during pregnancy.cite journalVandeVusseLHansonLSafdarNPerinatal outcomes of prenatal probiotic and prebiotic administration: an integrative review.The Journal of perinatal & neonatal nursing2013274288–301; quiz E1-224164813
article.heading: Complications
article.paragraph: Although previously considered a mere nuisance infection, untreated bacterial vaginosis may cause complications, such as increased susceptibility to sexually transmitted infections including HIV andpregnancy complications.cite webhttp://www.cdc.gov/std/bv/STDFact-Bacterial-Vaginosis.htm#ComplicationsSTD Facts — Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)4 December 2007CDChttps://web.archive.org/web/20071203214825/http://www.cdc.gov/std/bv/STDFact-Bacterial-Vaginosis.htm3 December 2007no

It has been shown that HIV-infected women with bacterial vaginosis (BV) have higher HIV concentrations in their vaginal secretions.cite journalJul 2005J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr393340–6Diagnostic criteria for BV have also been associated with a female genital tract factor that induces expression of HIV.The elevated HIV copy number in vaginal secretions of women with BV has been associated with an increased risk of heterosexual transmission of HIV.cite journal2012PLoS Med96e100125110.1371/journal.pmed.1001251

There is evidence of an association between BV and increased rates of sexually transmitted infections such as HIV/AIDS.BV is associated with up to a six-fold increase of HIV shedding. There is also a correlation between the absence of vaginal lactobacilli and infection of Neisseria gonorrhoeae andChlamydia trachomatis. BV is a risk factor for viral shedding and herpes virus type 2 infection. BV may increase the risk infection or reactivation of HPV.

In addition, bacterial vaginosis anintercurrent disease in pregnancymay increase the risk ofpregnancy complications, most notablypremature birthormiscarriage.Bacterial vaginosisfromNational Health Service, UK. Page last reviewed: 03/10/2013Pregnant women with BV have a higher risk of chorioamnionitis, miscarriage, preterm birth, premature rupture of membranes, and postpartum endometritis. BV is associated with gynaecological and obstetric complications. Data suggest an association between BV, tubal factor infertility, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Women with BV who are treated with vitro fertilization have a lower implantation rate and higher rates of early pregnancy loss.
article.heading: Epidemiology
article.paragraph: BV is the most common infection of the vagina in women of reproductive age.The percentage of women affected at any given time vary between 5% and 70%.BV is most common in parts of Africa and least common in Asia and Europe.In the United States about 30% of those between the ages of 14 and 49 are affected.Rates vary considerably between ethnic groups within a country.
